title: Diagnosis Definition
description: Schema for diagnosis definitions in the diagnosis quiz tool

criteria_summary.description: Summary of diagnostic criteria based on DSM-5 or ICD-10
criteria_summary.example: Five or more of the following symptoms present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning: depressed mood, diminished interest or pleasure, significant weight change, sleep disturbance, psychomotor agitation or retardation, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, diminished concentration, recurrent thoughts of death.

prevalence_rate.description: Annual prevalence rate in the general population (percentage)

key_features.description: Key clinical features that help identify this diagnosis (optional)
example: Depressed mood most of the day

child.example: Irritability may be more prominent than sadness

adolescent.example: May present with academic decline and social withdrawal

older_adult.description: Notes specific to older adult presentation
older_adult.example: May present with somatic complaints and cognitive complaints

example.name: Major Depressive Disorder
example.criteria_summary: Five or more depressive symptoms present during the same 2-week period, representing a change from previous functioning, with at least one symptom being depressed mood or loss of interest/pleasure. Symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
key_features: Depressed mood most of the day
Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt
Diminished ability to think or concentrate

age_specific_notes.child: Irritability may be more prominent than sadness; may present with somatic complaints
age_specific_notes.adolescent: Often presents with academic decline, social withdrawal, and risk-taking behaviors
age_specific_notes.adult: Typically presents with work-related difficulties and relationship problems
age_specific_notes.older_adult: May present with somatic complaints, cognitive complaints, and functional decline
